OriginalStatements: Managing down operating costs within such a complex technology environment is extremely difficult. Retiring applications that are tightly coupled within the technical and data architecture results in nearly insurmountable dependency management issues and change risk. Seemingly small projects quickly become big, expensive efforts with extended timeframes. Retiring one application inevitably requires upstream and downstream changes and this added cost erodes the business case and often leads to a decision to leave things as they are.
ExplainedStatements: Handling the costs of running advanced technology systems is very hard. Because of this, stopping the use of programs that are connected in complicated ways within the detailed system and data setup often leads to really big problems with managing relationships and a lot of risk when making changes. So, even small and simple projects can quickly become huge and too costly, taking much longer than expected. Also, stopping the use of just one program usually means making a lot of changes before and after it in the system, and these extra, unexpected costs can greatly reduce the value of the original plan. So, companies often choose to keep things as they are, mainly because the good things they thought would happen are hidden by the difficulty and expense of making the needed changes.

OriginalStatements: In this editorial for the collection on complexity in mental health research, we introduce and summarize the inaugural contributions to this collection: a series of theoretical, methodological, and empirical papers that aim to chart a path forward for investigating mental health in all its complexity... From physics to ecology, there is a rapidly evolving body of interdisciplinary research dedicated to investigating complex systems.
ExplainedStatements: In this thought-stirring article, which is a key starting point for the full set of writings on the many-sided topic of how complicated mental health research is, we carefully present and quickly give an overview of the leading work in this creative set of writings. Additionally, this varied group of deep-thinking, high-level, and detailed real-world studies eagerly sets out to make a map for a forward-moving way to look deeply into mental health in all its detailed difficulty. Also, pulling from the basic ideas of how things move and work to the lively connections in the study of living things and their environments, there is a quickly growing amount of very new research that mixes different fields of study. This passionate commitment to looking into the subtle details of complicated systems is not just new and important but also vital for making our knowledge of mental health better.

OriginalStatements: Throughout the twentieth century, much of psychiatry aspired to reductionist simplicity... However, far from uncovering simple etiologies, the past century of psychiatric research has revealed systematic complexity, leading to a growing recognition that mental disorders are dauntingly complex phenomena.
ExplainedStatements: Throughout the very eventful 1900s, a lot of the study of mental health conditions stubbornly aimed for easy-to-understand causes, really wanting clear-cut reasons for these conditions. Even though they really wanted this, they ran into a lot of problems and things that slowed them down. But still, the people studying these things kept trying to learn more. Because of this, instead of finding easy, single-reason causes, years of very careful study in mental health have shown us a very detailed and organized picture of how complicated these issues are. This discovery has been both eye-opening and a bit scary. So, there's been a growing awareness that mental health conditions are really complicated and need many different ways to be fully understood, diagnosed, and treated.

OriginalStatements: Impulses travel along nerves at a speed called the nerve conduction velocity (NCV). This velocity has been extensively measured in human peripheral nerves because of its utility in clinical medicine. Appreciably decreased NCV can be an important indicator of nerve injury or disease
ExplainedStatements: Signals zip through nerves super fast, which is called nerve speed (NCV). Because of this, doctors have carefully and thoroughly checked how fast these signals go in the nerves that are not in the brain or spinal cord, mainly because it's really useful in medical care. So, if this nerve speed is slower than usual, it can be an important sign that there might be nerve damage or a brain-related sickness. Also, by noticing changes in how fast nerves send signals, medical workers can figure out, take care of, and keep an eye on different diseases that affect the nerves.

OriginalStatements: Social isolation also comes with significant risk of mental health and neuropsychiatric disorders, including chronic anxiety and depression. Alongside this complex aetiology, social isolation has been linked to the increased prevalence of substance use disorders across a range of drug types, where social isolation both predicts drug abuse, and drug abuse occurs as a consequence of social isolation. Unfortunately, when socially isolated individuals wish to moderate or quit drug-intake, quitting is more difficult and less successful, limiting the likelihood of a long lasting recovery
ExplainedStatements:
Being alone a lot can really increase the chance of having serious mental health problems and long-lasting feelings of worry and sadness. It can also lead to using drugs more often among different kinds of drugs. Because of this, being alone a lot both leads to and makes drug use problems worse. Also, using drugs often happens because someone feels very alone, which starts a hard-to-stop cycle of feeling alone and using drugs.

Sadly, when people who feel very alone try to use drugs less or stop using them completely, it's much harder for them to stick with it and succeed. This makes it less likely for them to stay off drugs for good. What's more, without friends or family to help, these people don't have the support or help they need to stop using drugs, which really shows how important it is to deal with both feeling alone and using drugs at the same time to help them get better.

OriginalStatements: Mental disorders arise from a host of components across biological, psychological, and social levels of analysis, intertwined in a web of complex interactions... We must go further and understand both the individual components and the complex interactions among them

OriginalStatements: In his numerous writings, Marx critiques capitalism by identifying its flaws... ExplainedStatements:

This leads to unfair differences in society that spread throughout its core. Also, Marx says that capitalism's repeating patterns always end up causing problems that make these differences worse.

Marx strongly believes that when the workers really understand how bad and built-in the problems are, they will have to stand up against their rich bosses. This moment of understanding, or awareness of their class, is very important for the workers to see how they are all connected and have the same goals. Moreover, Marx thinks that this moment of understanding is bound to happen because of the way history naturally unfolds.

To start the needed and sure-to-happen change to communism, Marx says that the workers must get rid of the current class system. He imagines a future where there are no classes and everyone shares the things used to make goods. In this kind of society, using people for work would stop, and sharing things would be based on what people need, not on making money. In the end, Marx's idea is a future where the problems of capitalism are fixed, and a new chapter in human history starts, without the burden of money-based unfairness.

OriginalStatements: To get a better idea of how lice evolved and spread, a team led by marine biologist Marina S. OriginalStatements: A constant failure rate (CFR) is indicative of externally induced failures, as in the constant hazard rate situation for non-repairable items. A CFR is also typical of complex systems subject to repair and overhaul, where different parts exhibit different patterns of failure with time and parts have different ages since repair or replacement. Repairable systems can show a decreasing failure rate (DFR) when reliability is improved by progressive repair, as defective parts which fail relatively early are replaced by good parts. ‘Burn in’ is applied to electronic systems, as well as to parts, for this purpose.
ExplainedStatements: In simpler terms, a steady constant failure rate (CFR) often means that something outside is causing items that can't be fixed to break down in a predictable way. Also, a CFR usually shows up in complex systems that get fixed and updated regularly. Because of this, in these systems, different parts break down at different times, and each part lasts for a different amount of time after being fixed or replaced. Additionally, systems that can be fixed might show a clear pattern of breaking down less often (DFR) when they are fixed well and often. This happens because the parts that usually break down too soon are changed out for stronger, better-quality ones. To make sure this method works well, a special 'burn in' process is carefully used on fancy electronic systems and on each part, with the specific goal of making them last longer.

OriginalStatements: It should be noted that, although the system engineering process is applicable in all phases of the life cycle, this is not to imply that any single organizational entity within a given project is responsible for the completion of all of the tasks necessary to accomplish these objectives. OriginalStatements: If being a spokesman for a generation is a fleeting occupation, being a symbol of an era is downright dangerous for anyone who has the bad luck to outlive it. ExplainedStatements: Being a voice for a group of people is a short-lived, temporary job; also, becoming a well-known representation of a time period is very risky for anyone who has to live longer than the time when they were important. OriginalStatements: This despite the fact that I can say (like everyone else on Harvard’s campus in the fall of 2003) that “I was there” at Facebook’s inception, and remember Facemash and the fuss it caused; also that tiny, exquisite movie star trailed by fan-boys through the snow wherever she went, and the awful snow itself, turning your toes gray, destroying your spirit, bringing a bloodless end to a squirrel on my block: frozen, inanimate, perfect—like the Blaschka glass flowers. OriginalStatements: If Dickens’s prose fiction has “defects”—excesses of melodrama, sentimentality, contrived plots, and manufactured happy endings—these are the defects of his era, which for all his greatness Dickens had not the rebellious spirit to resist; he was at heart a crowd-pleaser, a theatrical entertainer, with no interest in subverting the conventions of the novel as his great successors D.H. ExplainedStatements:
Charles Dickens wrote stories that many people love, but some people say they have problems like too much drama, too much emotion, very obvious happy endings, and plots that seem too made-up. Even though he was a great writer, Dickens didn't try to change the usual way of writing in his time, which was the Victorian era. He liked to make his readers happy and was very good at entertaining them with his showy style. He didn't really want to change the traditional way of writing stories. Unlike Dickens, later famous writers like D.H. Lawrence, James Joyce, and Virginia Woolf really wanted to do something different with their writing.

Also, Dickens didn't write about people's relationships and feelings in the clever and often hidden way that George Eliot and Thomas Hardy did. These writers brought a new level of emotional detail and smart writing about real life to English stories, something that hadn't been done before. While Dickens did some new things with his writing, he didn't explore the complicated ways people think and feel like the writers who came after him did. So, even though his books were very popular and are still read today, they didn't lead to the new writing styles that changed literature after he died.

OriginalStatements: F. Scott Fitzgerald’s The Great Gatsby by no means serves as a blanket condemnation of the American dream; instead, the author uses the novel and its upwardly mobile protagonist to celebrate the ability of those not born of wealth to rise to the pinnacle of American society while also examining the costs that can accompany such success. When this duality is understood, the book’s descriptions of the glittering banality of the upper-class lifestyle can be seen as a critique of the hollowness of strictly material success, rather than simply demonstrating that Fitzgerald possessed, as Trilling described it, “a taste for aristocracy.”
ExplainedStatements: F. Scott Fitzgerald's book, "The Great Gatsby," is more than just a simple story about wanting to be rich; it's a deep look at the American dream. The smart writer, Fitzgerald, uses the story and its main character, who really wants to move up in society, to show how people who aren't born rich can still work hard and reach the top. But the book also shows that getting rich quickly can have big personal costs. When you really understand the story, you see that the bright and showy but empty life of the rich people is actually being criticized. This view shows that just having money doesn't truly make you happy. So, the book isn't just showing off Fitzgerald's good understanding of rich people's ways, as Lionel Trilling cleverly said.

OriginalStatements: For instance, when provided with a pollen-generating food source, bees will develop the capacity to feed on pollen, known as pollinivory; this finding does help to explain the explosion in bee species some 120 million years ago. The study also validates the theory that bees evolved from a species of carnivorous wasps. While pollinivory was confirmed as an important step in the process of bee speciation, the study overturned the previous hypothesis that this factor by itself was the cause of the diversification of bee species.
ExplainedStatements: For example, when bees have a lot of pollen to eat all the time, they slowly get really good at eating pollen. This change in what they eat is called pollinivory. Because of this interesting discovery, we can better understand why there was a big increase in the number of different kinds of bees around 120 million years ago. Also, this detailed study strongly supports the old idea that bees came from a group of meat-eating, hunting wasps. While eating pollen was an important change that helped create new types of bees, the study carefully proved that the old, too simple idea that this change was the only reason for the many different kinds of bees was wrong. So, the research points out that many things together, not just one thing, probably led to the wide variety of bees we see now.

OriginalStatements: Though volcanic eruptions emit carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas, the atmospheric concentration of this gas is about 16000 times the amount released by volcanic eruptions; therefore, no matter how large a volcanic eruption is, it cannot produce a significant change in the atmospheric carbon dioxide levels. Further, the total amount of carbon dioxide emitted per year by volcanic eruptions – between 130 and 230 million tons – is roughly equivalent to that emitted in only three to five days of human activity.
ExplainedStatements: Even though volcanoes can spit out carbon dioxide, a strong gas that traps heat, the amount of this gas in the air is about 16000 times more than what even the biggest volcano eruptions can release. So, even the biggest eruptions from volcanoes can't really change the amount of carbon dioxide in the air. Also, if you look at the big picture, the total carbon dioxide that volcanoes throw out every year—somewhere between 130 and 230 million tons—is pretty much the same as what humans make in just three to five days with non-stop factory and other work. This shows that volcanoes don't play a big part in the way carbon moves around these days and really points out how much more humans affect the air and the world.

OriginalStatements: Most of Werner's metaphorical moments were painterly - the juxtaposing of the wild bird and the tame tree, the shimmer of the periwinkle, the splurt of titanium white that fell from it onto the pavement. He loved New York for its simple surprises, although in truth, Oregon and Iowa and Arizona and everywhere else had simple surprises as well. Cantaloupe-colored sunrises, banded cows, Dairy Queens, all kinds of things that didn't include black plastic mountains of trash and the smell of dog urine.
ExplainedStatements:
Werner had a sharp eye for the beauty around him. In fact, his beautifully symbolic scenes were often like paintings. For example, the contrast between the wild bird and the calm tree was striking. Also, the gentle glow of the light blue flower was amazing to see, and the sudden splash of bright white paint that fell from it onto the old sidewalk added an unexpected element to the city scene.

Furthermore, Werner loved New York for its simple, surprising moments. But it's worth mentioning that places like the green state of Oregon, the wide-open spaces of Iowa, and the dry state of Arizona, along with many other places, had their own special simple surprises too. Each location had its own mix of experiences and sights that drew him in different ways.

Take, for instance, the orange sunrises that colored the sky with a hopeful start to each day. Or the cows that seemed to lounge around in the fields, offering a peaceful view compared to the busy city life he was used to. And we can't overlook the old-fashioned ice cream shops that brought back memories of classic American life and simpler times.

These charming things were very different from the less pleasant parts of city living, like the big piles of black garbage bags and the strong, unpleasant smell of dog pee that often filled the streets. While these were part of city life, they didn't win Werner's love like the more attractive and picture-perfect parts of America did. His love for beauty went beyond his immediate surroundings, finding something special in both the impressive nature and the small details of daily life.

OriginalStatements: The Times, in a welcome but highly uncharacteristic embrace of anarchy, celebrated this development as an ingenious guerrilla tactic in youth's eternal war against adult authority-"a bit of techno-jujitsu," as the paper put it. But it's not entirely clear which side is the winner here. When you hear the tone, it apparently sets your teeth on edge, which means that, if the entire class suddenly grimaces, it's a good bet that one of the students just got a text message.
ExplainedStatements:
The respected newspaper, The Times, unexpectedly and in a way that's not typical for them, happily praised this sneaky and smart move as a very clever and creative way to fight back in the ongoing struggle between young people who want to challenge the usual ways and the older, established powers. They called it a smart mix of technology and martial arts. But who will win this clever fight is still not clear. When that sharp sound happens, it feels like it's cutting through you and it's so intense it's hard to stand. This means that if all the students in the class make a face like something is bothering them, it's a good sign that one of the students who knows a lot about technology got a text without the teacher noticing.

Also, the high sound of the text alert is made to be heard by kids, who can hear higher sounds better, and it becomes a hidden way for them to talk without the adults knowing. So, it's important to think about whether this secret way of communicating is really good for the students over time. It shows they're smart and can change easily, but it might also accidentally make the gap between different ages bigger. So, while it might look like the kids who don't want to follow the rules are winning right now, what this means for the future and how teachers and students will get along as technology changes is still something we don't know everything about.

OriginalStatements: And finally, for most Americans, the War of Imagination - built of nationalistic excitement and ideological hubris and administration pronouncements about "spreading democracy" and "greetings with sweets and flowers," and then about "dead-enders" and "turning points," and finally about "staying the course" and refusing to "cut and run" -began, under the pressure of nearly three thousand American dead and perhaps a hundred thousand or more dead Iraqis, to give way to grim reality.
ExplainedStatements: As time went on, and especially for most people in the United States, the intensely dreamed-up War of Imagination—made from a strong combination of passionate love for one's country, stubborn belief in one's own ideas, and a lot of strong statements from the government about "spreading freedom" and "being greeted with sweets and flowers"—started to face problems. At first, this dream was supported by ignoring any talk of "people who won't give up" and being hopeful about "big changes coming." But as the war kept going, it got harder to believe this story. Even though people kept saying they would "keep going" and strongly said they wouldn't "give up and leave," what was really happening couldn't be overlooked. As a result, with the non-stop impact of almost three thousand American deaths and the huge number of maybe a hundred thousand or more deaths in Iraq, the once-solid image of the War of Imagination started to fall apart. This breakdown showed the harsh and strict reality, a serious wake-up call about the big difference between hopeful guesses and the tricky nature of war.

OriginalStatements: In the last hundred years intellectual advances of science and politics have in like fashion been crystallized into material of instruction and now resist further change. I would not say that the spirit of teaching is hostile to that of liberal inquiry, but a philosophy which exists largely as something to be taught rather than wholly as something to be reflected upon is conducive to discussion of views held by others rather than to immediate response. Philosophy when taught inevitably magnifies the history of past thought, and leads professional philosophers to approach their subject-matter through its formulation in received systems.
ExplainedStatements: Over the past hundred years, big changes in science and politics have become firmly set in the way we teach, and now they hardly change at all. While I wouldn't say that the basic idea of teaching is clearly against the idea of serious, open-minded questioning, it's true that when philosophy is mostly something to be taught, not deeply thought about, it tends to lead to long talks about what other people think. Because of this, teaching often ends up focusing on quick, gut reactions instead of deeper thinking, which gets lost. Also, when philosophy is taught in a step-by-step way, it usually ends up focusing a lot on what people thought in the past. This makes professional philosophers usually deal with their complex topics by looking at them through the ideas that are already well-known and accepted, instead of looking at them in new or modern ways.

OriginalStatements: It was the preliminary dwarfing and deliquescence of the mature old beside the embryonic mass of the new. It was impossible then—it is, I believe, only beginning to be possible now—to estimate the proportions, possibilities, and inter-relations of the new social orders out of which a social organization has still to be built in the coming years. No formula of definite reconstruction had been evolved, or has even been evolved yet, after a hundred years.
ExplainedStatements: At first, the difference was very clear: the big, old, powerful organizations began to get smaller and weaker, while at the same time, the growing, new, young ideas and systems started to appear. Back then, it was completely impossible to guess the true sizes, huge opportunities, and complicated connections of these new beginnings. Also, from this mess, a well-connected social group has not been carefully made yet in the years that are coming. As a result, no detailed plan for building everything again had been thought of at that important moment, and it's important to say that, even after a hundred years, such a plan has not been completely made yet.

OriginalStatements: We are never so apt to lose our sense of proportion as when we consider those beloved writers whom we hold to be humourists because they have made us laugh. It may be conceded that, as a people, we have an abiding and somewhat disquieting sense of fun. We are nimble of speech, we are more prone to levity than to seriousness, we are able to recognize a vital truth when it is presented to us under the familiar aspect of a jest, and we habitually allow ourselves certain forms of exaggeration, accepting, perhaps unconsciously, Hazlitt's verdict: "Lying is a species of wit, and shows spirit and invention."
ExplainedStatements: We often risk losing our sharp ability to judge fairly when we think about those special writers we love because they make us laugh a lot. It's true that we generally have a strong and sometimes uncomfortable love for humor. Also, we talk in a quick and witty way, so we usually prefer jokes over serious talk. Plus, we're really good at noticing important ideas when they're presented in a way that seems like a joke we know well. In this way, we often allow ourselves to exaggerate a lot, maybe without fully realizing it, agreeing with Hazlitt's bold opinion: "Telling tales is a kind of cleverness, and it shows creativity and energy."

OriginalStatements: The stage in these volumes presents itself indeed not merely as a mirror of life, but as an illustration of the utmost intensity of life, in the fortunes and characters of the players. Ups and downs, generosity, dark fates, the most delicate goodness, have nowhere been more prominent than in the private existence of those devoted to the public mimicry of men and women. Contact with the stage, almost throughout its history, presents itself as a kind of touchstone, to bring out the bizarrerie, the theatrical tricks and contrasts, of the actual world.
ExplainedStatements:
Truly, the fancy and complex plays in these detailed books are not just a simple copy of normal life. They actually show a clear, strong picture of the most intense and exciting parts of life, all wrapped up in the wild lives and the deep personalities of the actors. Also, the crazy changes, endless kindness, worst possible outcomes, and the most beautifully gentle acts of goodness are shown more clearly and importantly in the private lives of those who give their all to pretend to be other people on stage.

Additionally, getting close to the stage, through its long history, always seems to act like a test. This test is meant to highlight the weirdest behaviors, smart stage tricks, and the clear, powerful differences, of the real world we live in. As a result, people who dive into the world of theater often see that the stage is like a small version of the bigger human experience, showing and making bigger the many feelings and stories that form our lives.

OriginalStatements: It is this salutary organ of the will of all which establishes, in civil right, the natural equality between men. It is this celestial voice which dictates to each citizen the precepts of public reason, and teaches him to act according to the rules of his own judgment, and not to behave inconsistently with himself. It is with this voice alone that political rulers should speak when they command; for no sooner does one man, setting aside the law, claim to subject another to his private will, than he departs from the state of civil society, and confronts him face to face in the pure state of nature, in which obedience is prescribed solely by necessity.
ExplainedStatements: Truly, this very helpful part of our shared decision-making power creates, in the world of fair laws, the built-in equal status that all people have. Moreover, it is this light, heavenly guidance that tells every person the important lessons of smart community thinking, which helps him to always act in line with the smart choices of his own careful thinking, and warns him not to act in a way that really doesn't match who he is. Because of this, it is with this strong guidance alone that political leaders should talk very clearly when they give out orders. As soon as one person ignores the law and boldly tries to force his random personal wishes on someone else, he leaves the helpful community of fair society. By doing this, he ends up facing the other person directly in the simple, pure state of nature, where the only rule to follow is the tough rule of what you must do to survive.

OriginalStatements: Evolutionary psychology takes as its starting point the uncontroversial assertion that the anatomical and physiological features of the human brain have arisen as a result of adaptations to the demands of the environment over the millennia. However, from this reasonable point of departure, these psychologists make unreasonable extrapolations. They claim that the behavior of contemporary man (in almost all its aspects) is a reflection of features of the brain that acquired their present characteristics during those earliest days of our species when early man struggled to survive and multiply.
ExplainedStatements: Evolutionary psychology is based on the idea that the detailed and complicated parts of the human brain developed because of constant changes in nature over a very long time. Starting from this strong basic idea, evolutionary psychologists jump to big, sometimes guess-based ideas. As a result, they say that the way modern people act in almost every possible part is a reflection of brain qualities that were shaped during important times in our history. In these key times, early humans fought hard to survive and spread their kind, and it is this fight, evolutionary psychologists believe, that has created a lasting effect on how we act today.

OriginalStatements: In regard to propaganda the early advocates of universal literacy and a free press envisaged only two possibilities: the propaganda might be true, or it might be false. They did not foresee what in fact has happened, above all in our Western capitalist democracies - the development of a vast mass communications industry, concerned in the main neither with the true nor the false, but with the unreal, the more or less totally irrelevant. In a word, they failed to take into account man's almost infinite appetite for distractions.
ExplainedStatements: Before, people who supported the idea of everyone being able to read and having a strong, free news system only thought about two very simple outcomes. At first, they believed that the spread information could be completely true, or on the other hand, it could be very obviously fake. But they didn't predict, and this is really important, what actually happened, especially in our Western countries with free markets and voting systems. Later on, a huge industry of sharing news and information grew, and it became focused mainly not on the clear difference between what's true or false. Instead, and this is quite unexpected, this industry pays more attention to things that feel dreamlike and are mostly not related to the main issue. To put it simply, and this is a big mistake they didn't see coming, they didn't consider how people almost have an endless, never-satisfied desire for things that distract them and make them feel nothing.

OriginalStatements: There must therefore be an intrinsic connection between the conditions and the structural adaptations of the organism, and, since the conditions of life cannot be determined by the animal itself, the adaptations must be called forth by the conditions. The selection theory teaches us how this is conceivable, since it enables us to understand that there is a continual production of what is non-purposive as well as of what is purposive, but the purposive alone survives, while the non-purposive perishes in the very act of arising. This is the old wisdom taught long ago by Empedocles.
ExplainedStatements: Because of the close relationship between a living thing and where it lives, there must be a deep, natural connection between the living conditions and the living thing's body changes. Also, since the living thing can't choose its own living conditions, these body changes must be caused by the world outside. To make this idea easier to understand, the theory of how traits are picked out explains this process. In detail, it shows us how new, different traits keep appearing, some by chance that don't work well and others that are helpful and work well. But we should remember that only the good, useful traits last. Meanwhile, the chance traits that don't work well are quickly gotten rid of as they start to show up. This idea of nature picking the best traits is not just a modern science idea but also reflects the old, smart ideas taught long ago by the thinker Empedocles, making a connection between old smart thinking and today's study of living things.

OriginalStatements: As their name suggests, rare collectibles are scarce, hard to find items. They can be antiques that are desirable because of their age, type of craftsmanship or some other unique feature that represents the past. Some rare collectibles are so old that they are considered to be antiquities - artifacts of an ancient civilization such as ancient Greek or ancient Chinese society. Alternatively, rare collectibles can be of very recent origin, sometimes being only a few years old. The common denominator of all rare collectibles, no matter what their type or age, is rarity. Frequently, because of their scarcity and their appeal, rare collectibles are also valuable.
ExplainedStatements:
Old and hard-to-find items, often called collectibles, are very rare and can be tough to locate. They might be old and valued items, sought after for their age, special way of being made, or some other standout trait that clearly shows something from the past. These items can also include very old treasures, like priceless objects from long-ago cultures such as ancient Greece or China.

On the other hand, some collectibles might be quite new, only a few years old. Even with this difference in age, what brings all collectibles together is how seldom they are found. As a result, often because they are not found often and many people want them, collectibles can be worth a lot of money. This natural worth often causes intense interest from people who collect things, making these items even more important in the world of collectibles.

OriginalStatements: Therefore, though the situation seems dark in the context of the confrontation between the superpowers, the silver lining is provided by amazing phenomenon that the very nations which have spent incalculable resources and energy for the production of deadly weapons are desperately trying to find out how they might never be used. They threaten each other, intimidate each other and go to the brink, but before the total hour arrives they withdraw from the brink.

What's weird is that the same countries that have spent a ton of money and effort making super dangerous weapons are now working really hard to make sure they don't actually use them. OriginalStatements: Irrespective of how small these differences might be, they are crucial, and the disequilibrium is maintained by air near the surface mixing with air higher up, which is typically appreciably cooler and lower in water vapor content. The turbulence, which takes its energy from the wind mixes the air. As the speed of wind increases, so does the turbulence, and consequently the rate of heat and moisture transfer. We can arrive at a detailed understanding of this phenomenon after further study. The transfer of momentum from wind to water, which occurs when waves are formed is an interacting-and complicated phenomenon.
ExplainedStatements: Even though these small changes might not seem important, they really are essential. In fact, the careful balance is kept by the active mixing of warm, damp air close to the ground with the much cooler, less damp air higher up. What's more, the strong swirling of air, powered with energy by the wind, mixes the air really well. As the wind gets faster, the swirling gets more intense. Because of this, the air can swap heat and dampness better. By looking closely and analyzing, we can get a full understanding of this detailed process. Also, the way the lively winds push the moving water, which is a key part in making waves, shows a complex and two-way event. This interaction shows how the air and the sea are linked, underlining why we should look at these natural systems together.

OriginalStatements: The interconnectedness of brain and body has tantalizing implications for our ability to both understand and treat illness. If some brain conditions start outside the brain, then perhaps therapies for them could also reach in from outside. Treatments that take effect through the digestive system, heart or other organs, for instance, would be much easier and less invasive to administer than those that must cross the blood–brain barrier, the brain’s first line of defence against pathogens and other insults from the body.
ExplainedStatements: The deep connection between the brain and body opens up exciting possibilities for better understanding and dealing with different sicknesses. As a result, if some brain problems start from outside the brain, then maybe new kinds of treatments could also work from outside. In particular, treatments that work through the stomach, heart, or other important parts of the body would be much easier and less harsh to give than those that have to get through the brain's tough protective wall, which is the brain's strong first shield against germs and other possibly dangerous attacks from the body. Additionally, this way of handling things could completely change how we think about helping with medical care, possibly leading to big improvements in how well and comfortably we can look after patients.

OriginalStatements: The French are certainly misunderstood: — but whether the fault is theirs, in not sufficiently explaining themselves, or speaking with that exact limitation and precision which one would expect on a point of such importance, and which, moreover, is so likely to be contested by us — or whether the fault may not be altogether on our side, in not understanding their language always so critically as to know “what they would be at” — I shall not decide; but ‘tis evident to me, when they affirm, “That they who have seen Paris, have seen every thing,” they must mean to speak of those who have seen it by day-light.
ExplainedStatements: People often think of the French as mysterious, and this idea continues. It's not clear if this is because they don't explain their thoughts clearly and carefully, as we expect on such an important subject that we often argue about, or if we just don't understand their language well enough to get what they mean. I won't make a decision on this, but it seems clear to me that when they say, "Seeing Paris is like seeing everything," they mean that you really understand it only if you've been there and seen it yourself during the day. So, this means that to really get what Paris and maybe French culture are all about, you need to see and experience it yourself.

OriginalStatements: But it was the figure you cut as an employee, on an employee’s footing with the girls, in work clothes, and being of that tin-tough, creaking, jazzy bazaar of hardware, glassware, chocolate, chicken-feed, jewelry, drygoods, oilcloth, and song hits—that was the big thing; and even being the Atlases of it, under the floor, hearing how the floor bore up under the ambling weight of hundreds, with the fanning, breathing movie organ next door and the rumble descending from the trolleys on Chicago Avenue—the bloody-rinded Saturday gloom of wind-borne ash, and blackened forms of five-storey buildings rising up to a blind Northern dimness from the Christmas blaze of shops.
ExplainedStatements:
You really stood out, not just by being there, but by being a simple, hardworking person among the others. You dressed in clothes good for work and treated everyone equally, becoming a key part of the busy, noisy, lively market. This place was like a colorful picture made of different tools, shiny dishes, tasty chocolate, healthy chicken food, sparkling accessories, various dry items, strong waterproof fabric, and popular music. So, the most important thing was that you represented the market's energy.

Also, you and the people you work with were like strong, never-resting supporters of this little world, working unseen below, paying close attention to the sounds of many people walking slowly above. Along with the sound of steps, there was the calming, nice sound of the nearby movie theater organ and the deep, ongoing noise from the streetcars on Chicago Avenue. Even more, among the heavy Saturday air filled with dust and dirty buildings, there was a clear difference. This difference came from the dark, cold North and the happy, bright lights of the shops during Christmas, making a beautiful pattern of light and dark that perfectly showed what city life is like.

OriginalStatements: The streets are paved now, and the telephone and electric companies are cutting down more and more of the shade trees–the water oaks, the maples and locusts and elms–to make room for iron poles bearing clusters of bloated and ghostly and bloodless grapes, and we have a city laundry which makes the rounds on Monday morning, gathering the bundles of clothes into bright-colored, specially-made motor cars: the soiled wearing of a whole week now flees apparitionlike behind alert and irritable electric horns, with a long diminishing noise of rubber and asphalt like tearing silk, and even the Negro women who still take in white people’s washing after the old custom, fetch and deliver it in automobiles.
ExplainedStatements:
The once charming streets are changing, now covered with smooth roads, and there's a clear difference with the annoying phone and power companies. These companies are constantly cutting down more and more of the big, beautiful trees—like the grand water oaks, the bright maples, and the tall locusts and elms. Because of this, these big trees are being swapped out for tall metal poles that hold ugly and spooky-looking bunches of wires, a change that people don't like to see around.

At the same time, the city is changing in other ways too. For example, there's a busy place that cleans clothes and starts its work every Monday morning. This new business happily picks up piles of dirty clothes in colorful, specially made cars. So, the dirty clothes from the whole week disappear quickly, hidden by the loud and eager sounds of car horns. When these cars full of clothes leave, they make a long, dying sound on the road that sounds like ripping silk, showing how change keeps going on and on.

Also, even the tough women of color, who really stick to the old way of washing white people's clothes, have changed with the times. These women, welcoming the new times, pick up and drop off the clothes in their own simple cars. This change shows how old habits and new ways are coming together, as the old methods are kept but changed by the easy things in today's life. The fact that these women have cars, even simple ones, shows the unstoppable push toward making everything modern that has affected every part of the community.

OriginalStatements: The defoliation of millions of acres of trees by massive infestations of gypsy moth caterpillars is a recurring phenomenon in the northeastern United States.
ExplainedStatements: Trees in many places are losing their leaves because hungry gypsy moth caterpillars keep eating them. This happens a lot in the northeast part of the United States and it's a big problem. Because of this, the area looks less pretty and animals that live there have trouble surviving. This also causes problems for businesses that need forests, like those that cut down trees for wood or places where people go to see nature. So, it's really important to come up with good plans to stop these caterpillars from causing harm. If we do this, we can help keep the forests nice and healthy for people and animals in the future.

OriginalStatements: Forest stands of red oaks, with their tannin-rich foliage, may even provide caterpillars with safe havens from disease.
ExplainedStatements: Thick forests with tall red oak trees, known for their strong leaves full of tannin, might give caterpillars a safe place to hide from widespread sickness. As a result, these caterpillars might do well in a place that keeps them safe from animals that might eat them and might also lower the chance of getting sick from germs spreading. Moreover, having such a living space could lead to more different kinds of life in the forest environment, since the caterpillars are food for many birds and other animals. So, taking care of red oak forests could play a big part in keeping the careful balance of these natural areas.

OriginalStatements: Although a historical lack of access to formal Spanish-language education initially limited the opportunities of some Chicanos to hone their skills as writers of Spanish, their bilingual culture clearly fostered an exuberant and compelling oral tradition.
ExplainedStatements: Many Chicanos didn't have the chance to learn to write Spanish well in school at first, which made it hard for them to get better at writing. But their culture, which mixed both English and Spanish, definitely helped them keep a strong storytelling tradition alive through spoken stories. This storytelling was a key part of who they were and mixed different tales and legends that everyone in the community could relate to. As time went on, this spoken tradition helped start a new wave of Chicano writers who began to write down these stories. So, even though it was hard to get a good education in Spanish at first, it ended up helping create a special and strong way of writing that has made a big difference in their community.

OriginalStatements: Works in English, however, often required the elimination of nuance or colloquialism, the adoption of a formal tone, and the adjustment of themes or ideas to satisfy the different demands of national publications.
ExplainedStatements: Books and articles in English often needed the careful removal of small, special details or local slang. Because of this, they usually had to choose a cleaner, more official way of writing. Also, they had to change complicated topics or thoughts to fit the strict rules of different magazines and newspapers from around the world. So, writers and people who change text from one language to another had to be really aware of language details and different cultures. This was very important to make sure that the new readers could connect with the changed work, but still keep the true meaning of the original writing.

OriginalStatements: Researchers reasoned that low-frequency sound waves, because they are so well described mathematically and because even small perturbations in emitted sound waves can be detected, could be transmitted through the ocean over many different paths and that the properties of the ocean's interior could be deduced on the basis of how the ocean altered the signals.
ExplainedStatements: Scientists carefully figured out that low-pitched sounds, which are really well explained by math formulas, are very useful for looking around the ocean.
